WRITING.TEXT: On some phones, the background wallpaper that you see for your apps is *not* the same as the wallpaper that you see on your lock screen. The lock screen is conceptually kind of similar to a screensaver (and in that scene, it did look like Gerald's lock screen).
Does anyone know what was on the orange t-shirt that both Cartman and Heidi were wearing in the first scene?

Unless you're aiming to make a batch of 48 hotdogs, in which case you're all right, because you need just four packs of hot dogs and six packs of buns.
These people are now in their 40s.
For all those asking: the cat landed on its paws, of course.

Actually, many of the earlier seasons had a fair amount of political/social satire as well. There were episodes about the Terry Schiavo case, stem cell research, global warming (several of them), etc. I could make a list, but I think that if you go through any list of earlier episodes and look into them, you'll find that most of them were directly addressing some current event of the time.
It's just easy to overlook the political/social context of the earlier episodes and call it the "surreal adventures of four boys" because it's been so long (15-20 years!) that we've forgotten the themes and controversies of those days.

You get more utility out of saving money, they get more utility out of spending it. People have different [utility discount rates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounted_utility). Just because your personal finance model works for you doesn't mean that it'll work for them.
It is not your responsibility to tell others how to live their lives; you can tell them how you choose to live yours, but the path to pick is theirs to decide. Some exceptions apply for egregious situations, e.g. don't let your friends get scammed on bad real estate, but what you described are not egregious situations at all.

2-hour, 10 mile drive? You can walk faster than that, let alone ride a bicycle.
Hell, there are *thousands* of people who can unicycle faster than that.
I'd find a person willing to do a coin-toss bet for 250 million dollars.

(Setting: The grocery store. THE MARK is standing in the milk aisle, trying to find the expiration date on a large carton of 2% milk.)
(Enter THE INTERROGATOR. Door chimes. THE INTERROGATOR strolls toward THE MARK, looking indecisive as to what to buy.)
THE INTERROGATOR: "How's it going?"
THE MARK: "Good--"
(THE MARK's head explodes.)
(Exit THE INTERROGATOR.)

You are completely wrong in literally every single part of your comment.
Why don't I spell it out for you? his products have no Value
Any product that sells at any price *must* have value, otherwise there would not be any buyers.
he did not invent much of anything
If you want to be technical about it, he holds a [number of patents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk#Invented_Patents). Besides that, there's a neat little company called SpaceX that is doing all kinds of *groundbreaking* work. It's his brainchild.
slap a cool sounding name on a battery car
Tesla Motors was named Tesla Motors before he bought it.
that basicly was invented 35 years ago
Patently, ridiculously, absurdly false. Tesla Motors' vehicles have represented an unprecedented improvement in electric vehicles. There was nothing even remotely close in 2005; let alone 1981.
acts like he needs a noble prize
That's just totally unfounded.
Thanks for all the pointers. These were very helpful.
Only for one episode though, right?

Gotcha. Thanks for clarifying . Your comments are helpful. What I meant by using gsubs is translate each character into a Ruby statement, then execute the resulting program.
This is a good idea. I think that might be an interesting project, maybe I'll take that on next. I'm currently learning Ruby, so I'm on the lookout for good exercises.

I know that bf interpreters can be very terse, but I'm not sure if this qualifies as *enormous*. The core of this is just a simple case statement and loop, as you suggested. I could shorten it further by taking the core logic out of the class (which is an unnecessary wrapper). What do you have in mind for translation using gsubs?

Yeah, and if everyone used a big reusable grocery bag instead of ten disposable plastic bags every time, maybe we wouldn't have so much goddamn trash everywhere. Have you heard of the [Great Pacific Garbage Patch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Pacific_garbage_patch)? It's basically an area the size of Texas covered in plastic detritus. Disposable plastic bags are an environmental nightmare.

WRITING.TITLE: I need a typewriter repairman in San Francisco.
WRITING.TEXT:
Fellow typewriter aficionados:
I have a delightful 1960 Olympia manual typewriter: a family heirloom that was in pristine condition until recently. I took it on a plane with me as hand luggage, and vibrations from turbulences appear to have damaged some internal component: the carriage no longer moves. Based on my poking around, it appears that some spring has either broken or become dislodged.
I read the repair guide listed in the sidebar, and various other repair guides online, but I don't have the time to do it myself (or the patience/proficiency with mechanical tools). I was wondering whether anyone here might know anyone in the greater SF bay area who is good at repairing typewriters.
No offense, but your stove area looks like a pretty serious fire hazard. I'd recommend some kind of insulation and fewer easily flammable goods in close proximity.
The Kelly bag can also get similarly expensive.

$20,000k = 20 million dollars in credit card debt. Even a serious spendthrift will find it difficult to dig this deep.
*Sorry for pedantry.*
I hadn't heard about this; thanks for posting the "old news". I'll check them out!
Their meme status is a bummer, because they are *excellent* chairs. They're so good that I really can't blame anyone for putting them in their dining/living rooms, but it does become a bit boring.

The iron connects to an app that provides ironing tutorials and real-time guides to improve your ironing technique
That doesn't sound like it's made for professional seamstresses to me.
In general, I am suspicious of the claim that a "smart iron" could significantly improve the productivity of an experienced seamstress, who will most likely already know water consumption, technique, etc. like the back of her hand.

Instead of buying a $1400 "smart" iron, you could have your laundry picked up and done for you for about 100 weeks ($14/load). That's nearly two years, which is probably longer than the life expectancy of this ridiculous gadget.

How to invest in an industry you dont know well?
Don't.
Invest in industries that you know well.
Remember: there is no pressure to invest all your money at once. Be patient and wait for opportunities that you understand.

Hahahah, I hope you're joking man.
I knew a guy who shorted Tesla once. This was right around the time when that consumer reports article came out and addressed all the problems that model S owners had with their vehicles (door handles never coming out, random roof squeaks etc.) . He started spamming on stock twits about Tesla calling it a dumpster fire and just generally trolling the bulls. Well not one week later he's sleeping and at the dead of night he is woken by a scent coming through his doorway. It took him a minute to wake up but he soon realized the smell was smoke. He runs down the stairs of his home and bursts into his kitchen where he sees an 8 foot flame shooting up out of his garbage can. About half his kitchen burned down before the fire department arrived and the damage cost was over 50 thousand. The investigation showed that his back door was tampered with and someone broke the lock to enter his home, indicating foul play. The craziest part was yet to come though. About 3 days after the event he's staying at a hotel while repairs are being done on his home and he orders some room service. The food comes up to his room and he opens the tray. Inside he finds the meal he ordered, but to the right of the plate are 8 burned matches (previously lit). And you wanna know something about those matches. They were meticulously arranged in a pattern that specifically resembled 2 letters.... "E. M." All I'm saying is be careful about what you post and the positions you take man. I'd hate to see another young trader wiped out, account wise or literally, trying to bet against Elon Musk.
Wololo
